Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story: I was scanning the pool, whistle ready, when I saw my little brother, Max, in the deep end—right where he wasn’t supposed to be. My heart jumped. As his sister, I knew he hated being called out in front of others, and we’d just talked last night about trusting each other more, about not embarrassing him in front of his friends. But as a lifeguard, I couldn’t ignore the rules. The deep end was off-limits for kids his age, and he was clearly struggling. I could already hear the supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding me that safety always comes first. But Max’s eyes met mine, wide and pleading, silently begging me not to make a scene. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—my duty to keep everyone safe, and my promise to treat my brother with respect and understanding. My hand hovered over my whistle, torn between blowing it and rushing to his side quietly, unsure which role I should let guide me.
